concepts.term: F equals m v squared over r

evidence: why doesn’t it just fall straight down? The answer is that there is always a centripetal force pointing inward
The centripetal force doesn’t change the magnitude of the velocity, but it does change its direction
Mathematically, the centripetal force is equal to mass times velocity squared, divided by the radius
torque causes a perpendicular change in angular momentum
This is the key point to understand precession: a perpendicular change leads to circular motion

triples.evidence: Mathematically, the centripetal force is equal to mass times velocity squared, divided by the radius: F equals m v squared over r.
triples.o: mass times velocity squared, divided by the radius

triples.evidence: When the change in a vector is always perpendicular to the vector itself, the result is circular motion.

evidence: There is always a centripetal force pointing inward, toward the center of the orbit.
The centripetal force doesn't change the magnitude of the velocity, but it does change its direction.
The centripetal force is equal to mass times velocity squared, divided by the radius.
When the change in a vector is always perpendicular to the vector itself, the result is circular motion.

In the orbital case, the velocity vector keeps changing direction, while in angular momentum, the same principle applies: torque causes a perpendicular change in angular momentum, and so the angular momentum vector itself traces out a circle.
This is the key point to understand precession: a perpendicular change leads to circular motion.
